children.value: In this tutorial I'll show you how to set up professional development process with help of continuous deployment.
We'll be using React with help of

but you can easily follow with any other project maintained with NPM. Even if you are not using NPM, you can adjust the core build and run scripts for your needs quite easily. By any means you don't have to have any React experience whatsoever. It's just a sample project that will be used to show the flow of setting up the environment.
You have to have an account on
. All of them are free. Travis CI has .org TLD for free repos and .com TLD for private repos. For this tutorial we'll use .org version for free repos.

properties.aria-label: create react project with create react app permalink

children.value: Open your terminal of choice in your work folder. For me, it's
cd ~/sandbox/
Within this folder, we'll create the React project with NPX (A tool for executing Node packages) that is pre-installed with NPM version 5.2+
npx create-react-app tutorial-cicd
Installation of boilerplate project will begin. When everything is good to go you'll see a message with list of commands that can be run within the app. We'll just
cd tutorial-cicd
command already dit it. Now we can start the app with:
npm start
New browser tab will get open with
and following page will be shown.
The good thing about create-react-app is that it has tests included out of the box so we don't have to set up anything. For the reference you can run tests within you folder with
npm test
You'll be prompted with few options of running your tests. Simple press
to run all tests. Only one test should be run with text
that checks if the app renders link that can be seen on
. Since React renders the link just fine, the test passes.
Now we have our project setup.

properties.aria-label: create github repo and link it to our app permalink

children.value: Create Github repo and link it to our app
If you already setup your Github account you are good to go, if not please register on
. After you login to Github, we'll create new repository. You can create new repository on
. Now we have repo created but still not linked to our app. We can do that with following commands

git remote add origin git@github.com:<your_github_username>/tutorial-cicd.git
git push -u origin master
in first command with your username. Also this way we are using SSH to connect our repo. If you don't want to use SSH auth you can use HTTPS versions.
If you've done everything correctly, you should see the app on Github under project
We have now working app that is connected to Github repo.

properties.aria-label: connect github repo with travis ci permalink

children.value: Connect Github repo with Travis CI
Now comes the part where we connect the repo with Travis CI. You should be logged in into Travis CI with the same Github account that has our
repo. You'll be afterwards redirected to Github for authorization.
After you have successfully logged in. Click on your profile logo in the upper right side of the dashboard, click
button. After that you should see a list of repositories on your Github account. If you don't see the
in the left side of the screen. It'll take few mins (don't know why it takes so much time to sync) to sync Github and Travis CI. After success you should see the
To tell Travis CI what to do, we must create
config file in our projects root directory.
touch .travis.yml
Within this file, we will specify language to be used in build, its version and script to be run.
Since we need JavaScript on server, we will use Node.js v12. For this demo we will run only our test and production build of create-react-app so we can add following to .travis.yml

language: node_js

node_js:
  - "12"

script:
  - npm test
  - npm run build
Let's try that. Push new file to Github repo with

git add .
git commit -m "add travis.yml config file"
git push
You should see either running (yellow) build, already finished build (green), or failed build (red).
Under it, there is a log of the build. If something failed, you will see there the appropriate error message.
If everything passed, you just run first build! Good job
Now we will create project on Heroku where we can run our app in the cloud. For that you need to create an account on their
. After you create and account, create new app on this
. Name the app as "-tutorial-cicd" and choose a region that is closer to your location. For me Europe. If the app name is already taken, just modify it slightly. Click "Create app".

properties.aria-label: map deployment method to github permalink

children.value: To link Heroku project with you Github repo, in the Herokus Deployment method, choose Github. Then find the Github repo project and connect it. In the Automatic deploys section, check the "Wait for CI to pass before deploy" and then click on "Enable Automatic Deploys".
To connect Travis and Heroku, we need to update .travis.yml file. But before updating the file, we need to create our secure api key. For this, you need to have both
CLI. After installation login to heroku CLI with
That will prompt you with e-mail and password for Heroku.
If you have both CLIs installed you will run
travis encrypt $(heroku auth:token) --add deploy.api_key
You will verify detected repository with
. Then it will prompt you what the CLI will overwrite our Travis config file with
. At last we will specify provider of our deploy to be heroku and app name. Final .travil.yml config file should look like this.

language: node_js

node_js:
  - "12"

script:
  - npm test
  - npm run build

deploy:
  provider: heroku
  app: <your_heroku_app_name>
  api_key:
    secure: <your_secure_key>
Now you can push changes to Github repo with

git commit -m "add deploy section to travis.yml"
git push

properties.aria-label: serve static files on heroku permalink

children.value: We have build our create-react-app to production version but we have not specified how to run such build. For that we will use
package. Sure there are better ways to do that but I have chosen the most straightforward for this tutorial. We need to install one extra dependency to our project
npm install --save serve
After that we will change our

{
    ...
    "scripts": {
        "start": "serve -s build",
        "build": "react-scripts build",
        "test": "react-scripts test",
        "eject": "react-scripts eject"
    }
    ...
}
We can again commit new changes

git commit -m "add serve package"
git push
After success CI in Travis, you should be able to see you app running on URL

You have now setup continuous deployment that will deploy your changes to production without human intervention. Only failed tests or build will need additional steps. Remember that you should create new git branch when developing new feature so another college can check your changes before they are deployed to production.
